Thank you.  The python code does indeed work, but I converted that 
example exactally to C++ and as soon as you advance the solution is 
when the core dump occurs.  I assume that this must be some sort of 
bug in the c++ interface?  From reading postings this group it would 
seem that most people use either the python or matlab interface.  
Would you suggest using this route?  I personally perfer to code in 
c/c++ which is why I was trying it this way.

regards,
darin



--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> Darin,
> 
> Try running python example 'mix1.py'.  This uses a Valve object, 
and 
> works for me.  One thing that would likely cause a segmentation 
> violation is if the Valve 'massFlowRate' method is called without 
the 
> Valve installed between an upsteam and a downstream reactor.  This 
> method calls the 'pressure' method of both connected reactors, and 
will 
>   fail if one or both are not connected.
> 
> Dave
> 
> 
> On Feb 24, 2004, at 7:46 AM, viehe69 wrote:
> 
> > Professor Goodwin,
> > My company is trying to get aquainted with cantera so that
> > we can stop using chemkin, which is exclusively what we use
> > at this time for PSR, PFR and equilibrium simulations.  I am very
> > familliar with c/c++ and I like the approach that you are using 
with
> > cantera.  I have been trying to setup a kinetics problem 
utilizing a
> > Valve object.  Is there something about its implementation that
> > requires something different that MassFlowController objects?  I 
can
> > use these but get a segmentation violation whenever I use a Valve.
> > I have checked your documentation but cannot seem to find any
> > information that is of help with this subject.
> >
> > Darin S. Viehe
